channel.title: Computation Skills Workshop
channel.description: A workshop series for computational and technical skills in the social sciences.

item.title: Literate programming with R Markdown
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Soltoff
item.description: Literate programming is a technique for meshing source code with a human-readable explanation of its logic. This approach is used widely in data science and the social sciences to enable reproducible research and open access. In this workshop, we introduce the R Markdown document format and practice developing notebooks interweaving source code, output, and written text.

item.title: Geospatial visualizations with sf
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Soltoff
item.description: R contains many different packages for importing, structuring, and visualizing geospatial datasets. A modern implementation, `sf`, uses the simple features format to encode spatial vector data. This method integrates directly into tidy workflows and visualization method such as `ggplot2`. In this workshop we will introduce the `sf` package and practice generating vector graphics for geospatial data using `ggplot2`.

item.title: Optimizing selection of color palettes
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Soltoff
item.description: Researchers frequently use color to communicate numeric values in a data visualization. Most software will implement a default algorithm to select a color palette, and these palettes frequently are hard-to-interpret or are incompatible with common forms of color blindness. In this workshop we will develop approaches to readily generate optimized color palettes for continuous and categorical variables.
